elements.content: By using a controllable pillared-layer method, a novel visible-light responsive metal–organic framework (MOF) photocatalyst NNU-36 has been rationally constructed. The synthesized NNU-36 is of broad-range visible light absorption and good chemical stability which are beneficial to its application of photocatalysis. Photocatalytic experiments reveal that NNU-36 is highly efficient for Cr­(VI) reduction and dye degradation in aqueous solution under visible light irradiation. Control experiments show that the pH value is vital for Cr­(VI) reaction, and meanwhile, the use of hole scavenger of methanol promotes the photocatalytic reduction significantly. It has been also demonstrated that NNU-36 is efficient for dye degradation, in which the introduction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) significantly enhances the photocatalytic efficiency of dye degradation. This study illustrates that the introduction of hole scavengers or oxidants in the MOF-mediated photocatalytic reaction is a feasible approach to enhance the catalytic efficiency by suppressing the recombination of photoexcited electron–hole pairs in MOFs photocatalysts.
elements.clean_text: By using a controllable pillared-layer method, a novel visible-light responsive metal-organic framework (MOF) photocatalyst NNU-36 has been rationally constructed. The synthesized NNU-36 is of broad-range visible light absorption and good chemical stability which are beneficial to its application of photocatalysis. Photocatalytic experiments reveal that NNU-36 is highly efficient for Cr(VI) reduction and dye degradation in aqueous solution under visible light irradiation. Control experiments show that the pH value is vital for Cr(VI) reaction, and meanwhile, the use of hole scavenger of methanol promotes the photocatalytic reduction significantly. It has been also demonstrated that NNU-36 is efficient for dye degradation, in which the introduction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) significantly enhances the photocatalytic efficiency of dye degradation. This study illustrates that the introduction of hole scavengers or oxidants in the MOF-mediated photocatalytic reaction is a feasible approach to enhance the catalytic efficiency by suppressing the recombination of photoexcited electron-hole pairs in MOFs photocatalysts.

elements.content:
Water pollutants of the Cr­(VI) ion and organic dyes are efficiently treated by photocatalysts of pillared-layer metal−organic frameworks.

Introduction

Nowadays, it is more and more urgent to support clean water since increasing areas on the earth are facing serious water pollution. A huge amount of wastewater is generated in many industrial processes which often contains a complex range of inorganic heavy metal ions and organic compounds. These inorganic and organic pollutants, including but not limited to lead, chromium, fertilizers, pesticides, plasticizers, and organic dyes, are usually highly toxic and not easy to direct biological treatment, causing diverse adverse health effects and severe environmental problems. Taking organic dyes, for example, the discharge of these chemically stable and not very biodegradable organic substances into the aquatic environment is alarming due to their toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic characteristics. Among inorganic pollutants, hexavalent chromium Cr­(VI) is notorious due to its high toxicity and nonbiodegradation, as well as the cause of DNA damage and cancers. However, the Cr­(VI) in water is difficult to enrich, which makes it much more costly and difficult to remove. In contrast to Cr­(VI), Cr­(III) exhibits low toxicity and environmental friendliness. Therefore, the reduction of Cr­(VI) to Cr­(III) is usually chosen as an effective technique in the wastewater treatment process.
elements.clean_text:
Water pollutants of the Cr(VI) ion and organic dyes are efficiently treated by photocatalysts of pillared-layer metal-organic frameworks.

Introduction

Nowadays, it is more and more urgent to support clean water since increasing areas on the earth are facing serious water pollution. A huge amount of wastewater is generated in many industrial processes which often contains a complex range of inorganic heavy metal ions and organic compounds. These inorganic and organic pollutants, including but not limited to lead, chromium, fertilizers, pesticides, plasticizers, and organic dyes, are usually highly toxic and not easy to direct biological treatment, causing diverse adverse health effects and severe environmental problems. Taking organic dyes, for example, the discharge of these chemically stable and not very biodegradable organic substances into the aquatic environment is alarming due to their toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic characteristics. Among inorganic pollutants, hexavalent chromium Cr(VI) is notorious due to its high toxicity and nonbiodegradation, as well as the cause of DNA damage and cancers. However, the Cr(VI) in water is difficult to enrich, which makes it much more costly and difficult to remove. In contrast to Cr(VI), Cr(III) exhibits low toxicity and environmental friendliness. Therefore, the reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) is usually chosen as an effective technique in the wastewater treatment process.

elements.content: Effective and economical techniques need to be developed to deal with these pollutants. Among various chemical, physical, and biological techniques in pollution control, photocatalysis is very attractive and draws much attention worldwide since it provides the possibility to employ renewable and abundant solar energy to promote reactions under mild conditions. Since the first photocatalysis study of TiO2, semiconductors including metal oxides and metal sulfides have been investigated to eliminate contaminants in water. Studies have revealed that these materials are effective for dye degradation and Cr­(VI) reduction, relying on the photoinduced electron and/or hole. However, these catalysts suffer from limitation of fast recombination of the electron–hole pairs, low solar energy utilization efficiency, and easy agglomeration. Therefore, new catalytic material showing high photocatlytic performance is desirable.
elements.clean_text: Effective and economical techniques need to be developed to deal with these pollutants. Among various chemical, physical, and biological techniques in pollution control, photocatalysis is very attractive and draws much attention worldwide since it provides the possibility to employ renewable and abundant solar energy to promote reactions under mild conditions. Since the first photocatalysis study of TiO2, semiconductors including metal oxides and metal sulfides have been investigated to eliminate contaminants in water. Studies have revealed that these materials are effective for dye degradation and Cr(VI) reduction, relying on the photoinduced electron and/or hole. However, these catalysts suffer from limitation of fast recombination of the electron-hole pairs, low solar energy utilization efficiency, and easy agglomeration. Therefore, new catalytic material showing high photocatlytic performance is desirable.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers, have evoked considerable attention in chemistry and materials science due to their intriguing properties. MOFs are potentially promising candidates to deal with the current environment and energy problems confronting human societies. The synthesis and application of MOFs with photon absorption property serving as heterogeneous photocatalysis to remove and degrade hazard materials by utilizing photoinduced electrons in MOFs has triggered much more interest. Interesting studies on the photocatalytic degradation of several organic dyes and reduction of Cr­(VI) have recently been reported. Typical examples shown by Zhao et al. have disclosed the MOF-based advanced oxidation processes (AOP) for Rhodamine B (RhB) degradation. AOP including the Fenton reaction, photocatalysis, sonolysis, ozonation, and combinations of these, involve in situ generation of highly reactive oxidants, such as hydroxyl radical and ozone, to degrade the persistent and nonbiodegradable organic substances into less toxic ones, even CO2 and H2O. In particular, the utilization of environmentally benign oxidants of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) producing hydroxyl radical to promote the catalytic reaction has attracted considerable attention. Ai et al. reported MIL-53­(Fe) as a photocatalyst using H2O2 on RhB degradation to achieve considerable efficiency under visible light irradiation. Li et al. demonstrated the composite of g-C3N4/NH2-MIL-88B­(Fe), which was used for visible-light induced photodegradation of methylene blue (MB). Recently, divertive MOF photocatalysis on the degradation of organic dyes by AOPs have been reported. Meanwhile, MOFs are efficient photocatalysts for aqueous Cr­(VI) reduction. Wang et al. disclosed the Cr­(VI) reduction by NH2-MIL-125­(Ti) as photocatalysts which showed relatively high efficiency. Other MOFs such as MIL-68­(In)-NH2 have also been demonstrated to be effective photocatalysts for Cr­(VI) reduction. These reports demonstrate the potential of MOF photocatalysts to degrade organic dyes and reduce Cr­(VI) pollutants in water. Most of the MOFs failed to carry out the desired photocatalytic reactions, primarily due to the lack of absorbance centers in the MOFs structures.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as coordination polymers, have evoked considerable attention in chemistry and materials science due to their intriguing properties. MOFs are potentially promising candidates to deal with the current environment and energy problems confronting human societies. The synthesis and application of MOFs with photon absorption property serving as heterogeneous photocatalysis to remove and degrade hazard materials by utilizing photoinduced electrons in MOFs has triggered much more interest. Interesting studies on the photocatalytic degradation of several organic dyes and reduction of Cr(VI) have recently been reported. Typical examples shown by Zhao et al. have disclosed the MOF-based advanced oxidation processes (AOP) for Rhodamine B (RhB) degradation. AOP including the Fenton reaction, photocatalysis, sonolysis, ozonation, and combinations of these, involve in situ generation of highly reactive oxidants, such as hydroxyl radical and ozone, to degrade the persistent and nonbiodegradable organic substances into less toxic ones, even CO2 and H2O. In particular, the utilization of environmentally benign oxidants of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) producing hydroxyl radical to promote the catalytic reaction has attracted considerable attention. Ai et al. reported MIL-53(Fe) as a photocatalyst using H2O2 on RhB degradation to achieve considerable efficiency under visible light irradiation. Li et al. demonstrated the composite of g-C3N4/NH2-MIL-88B(Fe), which was used for visible-light induced photodegradation of methylene blue (MB). Recently, divertive MOF photocatalysis on the degradation of organic dyes by AOPs have been reported. Meanwhile, MOFs are efficient photocatalysts for aqueous Cr(VI) reduction. Wang et al. disclosed the Cr(VI) reduction by NH2-MIL-125(Ti) as photocatalysts which showed relatively high efficiency. Other MOFs such as MIL-68(In)-NH2 have also been demonstrated to be effective photocatalysts for Cr(VI) reduction. These reports demonstrate the potential of MOF photocatalysts to degrade organic dyes and reduce Cr(VI) pollutants in water. Most of the MOFs failed to carry out the desired photocatalytic reactions, primarily due to the lack of absorbance centers in the MOFs structures.

elements.content: Herein, we report a new MOF photocatalyst which is synthesized by a controllable pillared-layer approach using visible-light harvesting bipyridine as a pillared ligand. Experiments reveal that the pillared-layer MOF is a highly efficient photocatalyst for aqueous Cr­(VI) reduction and dye degradation under visible light. We also demonstrate here that the addition of hole scavenger and oxidant in the MOF-mediated photocatalytic reactions is a feasible approach to enhance photocatalytic efficiency.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a new MOF photocatalyst which is synthesized by a controllable pillared-layer approach using visible-light harvesting bipyridine as a pillared ligand. Experiments reveal that the pillared-layer MOF is a highly efficient photocatalyst for aqueous Cr(VI) reduction and dye degradation under visible light. We also demonstrate here that the addition of hole scavenger and oxidant in the MOF-mediated photocatalytic reactions is a feasible approach to enhance photocatalytic efficiency.

elements.content: All chemicals except the pillaring ligand of 9,10-bis­(4′-pyridylethynyl)-anthracene (BPEA) (see Supporting Information) are of analytical grade and used as received from suppliers without further purification. Pillared-layer MOF (named NNU-36) was solvothermally prepared by a reaction of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (47 mg, 0.16 mmol), BPEA (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), and 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate (BPDC) (38 mg, 0.15 mmol) dissolved in a mixed solvent of DMF/DMA/H2O (19 mL, 11:4:4, v/v/v). The reaction was carried out in an autoclave and kept at 85 °C for 3 days. Brown plate-shaped single crystals of NNU-36 were obtained and washed with DMF and ethanol several times for further use. Yield: ca. 65.5% based on BPEA. The details of single-crystal data collection and refinement, as well as physical characterizations for bulk samples are provided in Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of Pillared-Layer NNU-36

All chemicals except the pillaring ligand of 9,10-bis(4'-pyridylethynyl)-anthracene (BPEA) (see Supporting Information) are of analytical grade and used as received from suppliers without further purification. Pillared-layer MOF (named NNU-36) was solvothermally prepared by a reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (47 mg, 0.16 mmol), BPEA (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), and 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (BPDC) (38 mg, 0.15 mmol) dissolved in a mixed solvent of DMF/DMA/H2O (19 mL, 11:4:4, v/v/v). The reaction was carried out in an autoclave and kept at 85 °C for 3 days. Brown plate-shaped single crystals of NNU-36 were obtained and washed with DMF and ethanol several times for further use. Yield: ca. 65.5% based on BPEA. The details of single-crystal data collection and refinement, as well as physical characterizations for bulk samples are provided in Supporting Information.

elements.content: The photocatalytic experiments for aqueous Cr­(VI) reduction of potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) were carried out at ambient conditions in a 150 mL quartz reactor containing 15 mg of NNU-36 and 40 mL of Cr­(VI) aqueous solution (10 ppm). The mixture was first stirred for 60 min in the dark to reach an adsorption–desorption equilibrium (Figure S1). 0.2 M H2SO4 was used to adjust the acidity in the reaction, where the pH values were determined by using a pH detector (Rex Instrument, Shanghai, China). Then, the suspensions were irradiated using a 300 W xenon arc lamp with a 420 nm cutoff filter. During the reaction, 1.5 mL of suspension was taken out each time from the reactor at a scheduled interval, and the photocatalyst was separated by centrifugation. Then, the Cr­(VI) content in the solution was determined colorimetrically by the diphenylcarbazide method (DPC) with a detection limit of 0.005 mg L–1. The measured maximum absorbance (centered at 540 nm) at different reaction times were transformed to the reduction ratio of Cr­(VI) using the following expression: reduction ratio of Cr­(VI) = (C 0 – C t)/C 0 × 100%.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Experiments

The photocatalytic experiments for aqueous Cr(VI) reduction of potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) were carried out at ambient conditions in a 150 mL quartz reactor containing 15 mg of NNU-36 and 40 mL of Cr(VI) aqueous solution (10 ppm). The mixture was first stirred for 60 min in the dark to reach an adsorption-desorption equilibrium (Figure S1). 0.2 M H2SO4 was used to adjust the acidity in the reaction, where the pH values were determined by using a pH detector (Rex Instrument, Shanghai, China). Then, the suspensions were irradiated using a 300 W xenon arc lamp with a 420 nm cutoff filter. During the reaction, 1.5 mL of suspension was taken out each time from the reactor at a scheduled interval, and the photocatalyst was separated by centrifugation. Then, the Cr(VI) content in the solution was determined colorimetrically by the diphenylcarbazide method (DPC) with a detection limit of 0.005 mg L-1. The measured maximum absorbance (centered at 540 nm) at different reaction times were transformed to the reduction ratio of Cr(VI) using the following expression: reduction ratio of Cr(VI) = (C 0 - C t)/C 0 × 100%.

elements.content: The photocatalytic experiments for the degradation of dyes of RhB, MB, and R6G were carried out at room temperature. Typically, 15 mg of photocatalyst and 40 mL of dye solution (10 ppm) were added into a 150 mL quartz reactor. After being stirred for 60 min in the dark to ensure the adsorption/desorption equilibrium (Figure S1), 30% H2O2 was added to the reaction solutions. After NNU-36 has been removed by centrifugation, the concentration of dyes in 1.5 mL of supernatant solution was determined at their maximum absorption wavelengths centered at 554, 664, and 524 nm, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The photocatalytic experiments for the degradation of dyes of RhB, MB, and R6G were carried out at room temperature. Typically, 15 mg of photocatalyst and 40 mL of dye solution (10 ppm) were added into a 150 mL quartz reactor. After being stirred for 60 min in the dark to ensure the adsorption/desorption equilibrium (Figure S1), 30% H2O2 was added to the reaction solutions. After NNU-36 has been removed by centrifugation, the concentration of dyes in 1.5 mL of supernatant solution was determined at their maximum absorption wavelengths centered at 554, 664, and 524 nm, respectively.

elements.content: The pillared-layer method has been demonstrated as a controllable approach to construct MOF materials with definite structural features. Typically, this method relies on the use of a carboxylic ligand to construct “carboxylate-metal” layers which are simultaneously pillared by an auxiliary ligand of bipyridines. Successful examples include series of MOFs constituted by zinc dimers, dicarboxylates, and bipyridines. However, the utilization of the pillared-layer method to synthesize MOF photocatalysts is rarely reported. It has been widely demonstrated that the use of visible light harvesting organic ligands is feasible to prepare MOF photocatalysts. In this content, BPEA is chosen here due to its broad-band absorption in the visible light region of 400–480 nm (Figure S2), due to π orbital transition. To prepare the target pillared-layer MOF, the stoichiometric ratio among zinc salt, BPDC, and BPEA was first fixed at 2:2:1 according to its expected structure. NNU-36 was first synthesized in a mixed solvent of DMF/H2O or DMA/H2O; however, the produced NNU-36 was not well crystallized, and the yield was low. By introducing DMA to the mixture of DMF/H2O, single crystals in high quality were prepared. The attempts to synthesize NNU-36 in high quality and good yield by using a monocomponent solvent of DMA, DMF, or water were not successful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The pillared-layer method has been demonstrated as a controllable approach to construct MOF materials with definite structural features. Typically, this method relies on the use of a carboxylic ligand to construct "carboxylate-metal" layers which are simultaneously pillared by an auxiliary ligand of bipyridines. Successful examples include series of MOFs constituted by zinc dimers, dicarboxylates, and bipyridines. However, the utilization of the pillared-layer method to synthesize MOF photocatalysts is rarely reported. It has been widely demonstrated that the use of visible light harvesting organic ligands is feasible to prepare MOF photocatalysts. In this content, BPEA is chosen here due to its broad-band absorption in the visible light region of 400-480 nm (Figure S2), due to π orbital transition. To prepare the target pillared-layer MOF, the stoichiometric ratio among zinc salt, BPDC, and BPEA was first fixed at 2:2:1 according to its expected structure. NNU-36 was first synthesized in a mixed solvent of DMF/H2O or DMA/H2O; however, the produced NNU-36 was not well crystallized, and the yield was low. By introducing DMA to the mixture of DMF/H2O, single crystals in high quality were prepared. The attempts to synthesize NNU-36 in high quality and good yield by using a monocomponent solvent of DMA, DMF, or water were not successful.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data manifest that NNU-36 possesses three-dimensional structure and crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c with a formula of [Zn2(BPEA) (BPDC)2]·2DMF. As shown in , the compound exhibits a pillared-layer structure constructed by “in-layer” zinc dimers and BPDC, and “interlayer” bipyridine pillars. In the structure, each Zn is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from dicarboxylate ligands within the layer and two apical nitrogen atoms from two pillaring ligands. The adjacent zinc ions with a Zn···Zn distance of 2.969 Å are connected by carboxylate groups to form zinc dimers in four-blade paddlewheel geometry. The bond lengths of Zn–O bonds are in the range of 2.031–2.054 Å, and the bond length of the Zn–N bond is 2.020 Å. These values are consistent with that of other Zn MOFs. It is notable that the zinc dimer in four-blade paddlewheel coordination is representative of zinc MOF structures synthesized by the pillared-layer approach. In the structure, the inorganic building blocks of zinc dimers are bridged by BPDC ligands to form metal-carboxylate layers showing 4 × 4 grids (b). The layers are further pillared by the BPEA ligand through Zn–N bonds to constitute the overall framework of NNU-36 (c). It is well-known that the phenomenon of interpenetration tends to emerge in MOFs structures more easily when the organic linker is large in size. NNU-36 displays a 4-fold interpenetrating structure, leading to a relatively dense structure (Figure S3). Notably, BPEA ligands exhibit two orientations to enhance the preferential π–π stacking interactions between different sets of frameworks (Figure S4). Two kinds of π–π interactions are observed in the structure where the face-to-face distance between BPEA pillars is measured to be ca. 3.4 Å and that between BPEA and BPDC is ca. 3.3 Å (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data manifest that NNU-36 possesses three-dimensional structure and crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/c with a formula of [Zn2(BPEA) (BPDC)2]⋅2DMF. As shown in , the compound exhibits a pillared-layer structure constructed by "in-layer" zinc dimers and BPDC, and "interlayer" bipyridine pillars. In the structure, each Zn is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from dicarboxylate ligands within the layer and two apical nitrogen atoms from two pillaring ligands. The adjacent zinc ions with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 2.969 Å are connected by carboxylate groups to form zinc dimers in four-blade paddlewheel geometry. The bond lengths of Zn-O bonds are in the range of 2.031-2.054 Å, and the bond length of the Zn-N bond is 2.020 Å. These values are consistent with that of other Zn MOFs. It is notable that the zinc dimer in four-blade paddlewheel coordination is representative of zinc MOF structures synthesized by the pillared-layer approach. In the structure, the inorganic building blocks of zinc dimers are bridged by BPDC ligands to form metal-carboxylate layers showing 4 × 4 grids (b). The layers are further pillared by the BPEA ligand through Zn-N bonds to constitute the overall framework of NNU-36 (c). It is well-known that the phenomenon of interpenetration tends to emerge in MOFs structures more easily when the organic linker is large in size. NNU-36 displays a 4-fold interpenetrating structure, leading to a relatively dense structure (Figure S3). Notably, BPEA ligands exhibit two orientations to enhance the preferential π-π stacking interactions between different sets of frameworks (Figure S4). Two kinds of π-π interactions are observed in the structure where the face-to-face distance between BPEA pillars is measured to be ca. 3.4 Å and that between BPEA and BPDC is ca. 3.3 Å (Figure S3).

elements.content: (a) Pillared-layer structure of NNU-36; (b) layer structure constituted by BPDC ligand and zinc dimer; (c) a view shows the pillaring ligand coordinated to layer in the structure. Blue, red, purple, and orange spheres/polyhedra represent nitrogen, oxygen, zinc, and carbon atoms, respectively. All hydrogen atoms and guest molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Pillared-layer structure of NNU-36; (b) layer structure constituted by BPDC ligand and zinc dimer; (c) a view shows the pillaring ligand coordinated to layer in the structure. Blue, red, purple, and orange spheres/polyhedra represent nitrogen, oxygen, zinc, and carbon atoms, respectively. All hydrogen atoms and guest molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed that crystals of NNU-36 are plate-shaped (Figure S5). The bulk phase of crystalline NNU-36 was examined by powder X-ray diffraction, where it matches well with the simulated one from crystal structure, indicating the purity of the as-prepared material (a). Considering the following photocatalysis study, the chemical stability of the MOF photocatalyst in aqueous solution is important. As shown in a, PXRD studies suggest that NNU-36 is stable enough to survive from water after being soaked for 1 week. Thermogravimetry measurement was executed to explore the thermal stability of NNU-36. The TG curve shows the first weight loss before 200 °C due to the removal of guest molecules of DMF (calcd. 12.50 wt %, obs. 12.11 wt %). As shown in Figure S6, the guest-free framework of NNU-36 shows a thermal stability up to ca. 350 °C; thereafter, a sharp weight loss attributed to the decomposition of the framework is observed. The peak at 2202 cm–1 on the FTIR spectrum is attributed to the stretching vibration of ethynyl (CC) groups in the pillared ligand (see Figure S7). The peaks at 1607, 1637, and 1392 cm–1 are due to vibrations of carboxylate groups in the BPDC ligand. The peaks at 837 and 769 cm–1 can be ascribed to the out-of-plane bending vibration of C–H bond in benzene groups belonging to both BPDC and BPEA ligands. The intense peak at 1683 cm–1 (v CO) confirms the presence of a guest DMF molecule in the structure. Several weak absorptions at 3055, 2943, 2918, and 2833 cm–1 corresponding to the vibrations of C–H bonds in the DMF molecule can be observed simultaneously. Evidently, the FTIR spectrum is in good accordance with crystal structure analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Characterizations

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed that crystals of NNU-36 are plate-shaped (Figure S5). The bulk phase of crystalline NNU-36 was examined by powder X-ray diffraction, where it matches well with the simulated one from crystal structure, indicating the purity of the as-prepared material (a). Considering the following photocatalysis study, the chemical stability of the MOF photocatalyst in aqueous solution is important. As shown in a, PXRD studies suggest that NNU-36 is stable enough to survive from water after being soaked for 1 week. Thermogravimetry measurement was executed to explore the thermal stability of NNU-36. The TG curve shows the first weight loss before 200 °C due to the removal of guest molecules of DMF (calcd. 12.50 wt %, obs. 12.11 wt %). As shown in Figure S6, the guest-free framework of NNU-36 shows a thermal stability up to ca. 350 °C; thereafter, a sharp weight loss attributed to the decomposition of the framework is observed. The peak at 2202 cm-1 on the FTIR spectrum is attributed to the stretching vibration of ethynyl (CC) groups in the pillared ligand (see Figure S7). The peaks at 1607, 1637, and 1392 cm-1 are due to vibrations of carboxylate groups in the BPDC ligand. The peaks at 837 and 769 cm-1 can be ascribed to the out-of-plane bending vibration of C-H bond in benzene groups belonging to both BPDC and BPEA ligands. The intense peak at 1683 cm-1 (v CO) confirms the presence of a guest DMF molecule in the structure. Several weak absorptions at 3055, 2943, 2918, and 2833 cm-1 corresponding to the vibrations of C-H bonds in the DMF molecule can be observed simultaneously. Evidently, the FTIR spectrum is in good accordance with crystal structure analysis.

elements.content: (a) PXRD patterns of NNU-36 (red) and NNU-36 soaked in water for 1 week (blue) and the simulated one (black) from crystal structure; (b) UV–vis spectrum of NNU-36; (c) Mott–Schottky plots of NNU-36 in 0.2 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution (pH 6.8). The insert in b shows the Tauc plot of NNU-36.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) PXRD patterns of NNU-36 (red) and NNU-36 soaked in water for 1 week (blue) and the simulated one (black) from crystal structure; (b) UV-vis spectrum of NNU-36; (c) Mott-Schottky plots of NNU-36 in 0.2 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution (pH 6.8). The insert in b shows the Tauc plot of NNU-36.

elements.content: The optical absorbance of NNU-36 was investigated by an UV–vis spectrometer. As shown in b, NNU-36 exhibits visible light absorption in a wide region with the edge at about 650 nm, which is potentially favorable to its application of visible light photocatalysis. The band gap energy of NNU-36 is then calculated according to the energy dependence relationship of αhν = ( hν – E g)1/2, where α and E g are the absorption coefficient and the energy gap of a semiconductor, respectively. The plot of (αhν)2 versus photon energy ( hν) is fitted linearly (inset in b), and the band gap energy of NNU-36 is estimated to be ∼2.28 eV. Considering that the absorbance of the carboxylic ligand BPDC falls into the ultraviolet region, the visible light absorption of as-prepared MOFs should originate from the pillared ligand of anthracene-based bipyridine. However, in contrast to the optical absorption of BPEA pillars, NNU-36 shows a broadened absorption in the low-energy region. This should be due to the energy transfer process from ligand to metal ion, which is commonly observed in MOF compounds. In order to better understand the intrinsic electronic properties of NNU-36, Mott–Schottky measurements were conducted. As shown in c, NNU-36 exhibits the typical behavior of n-type semiconductors where the positive slope of C 2 values versus potential is observed. The intersection of the plots is independent of frequency. Therefore, the flat-band potential of NNU-36 determined from Mott–Schottky plots is ca. −1.37 V versus the Ag/AgCl electrode at pH 6.8. Therefore, the redox potential of the conduction band (CB) of NNU-36 is −1.17 V versus normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) at pH 6.8. By combining the band gap result, the valence band (VB) of NNU-36 is then calculated to be 1.11 V vs NHE.
elements.clean_text: The optical absorbance of NNU-36 was investigated by an UV-vis spectrometer. As shown in b, NNU-36 exhibits visible light absorption in a wide region with the edge at about 650 nm, which is potentially favorable to its application of visible light photocatalysis. The band gap energy of NNU-36 is then calculated according to the energy dependence relationship of αhν = ( hν - E g)1/2, where α and E g are the absorption coefficient and the energy gap of a semiconductor, respectively. The plot of (αhν)2 versus photon energy ( hν) is fitted linearly (inset in b), and the band gap energy of NNU-36 is estimated to be ~2.28 eV. Considering that the absorbance of the carboxylic ligand BPDC falls into the ultraviolet region, the visible light absorption of as-prepared MOFs should originate from the pillared ligand of anthracene-based bipyridine. However, in contrast to the optical absorption of BPEA pillars, NNU-36 shows a broadened absorption in the low-energy region. This should be due to the energy transfer process from ligand to metal ion, which is commonly observed in MOF compounds. In order to better understand the intrinsic electronic properties of NNU-36, Mott-Schottky measurements were conducted. As shown in c, NNU-36 exhibits the typical behavior of n-type semiconductors where the positive slope of C 2 values versus potential is observed. The intersection of the plots is independent of frequency. Therefore, the flat-band potential of NNU-36 determined from Mott-Schottky plots is ca. -1.37 V versus the Ag/AgCl electrode at pH 6.8. Therefore, the redox potential of the conduction band (CB) of NNU-36 is -1.17 V versus normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) at pH 6.8. By combining the band gap result, the valence band (VB) of NNU-36 is then calculated to be 1.11 V vs NHE.

elements.content: The use of NNU-36 as a visible light photocatalyst for the reduction of aqueous Cr­(VI) was performed since it shows broad-range visible light absorption and good stability. Control experiments were first carried out to illustrate the photocatalytic nature of the reaction. As shown in a, there is no significant reduction of Cr­(VI) in the dark or in the absence of a photocatalyst. It is well-known that the reduction rate of aqueous Cr­(VI) over photocatalysts is greatly influenced by pH values of the solution. Hence, the influence of pH values on the reaction was investigated. The temporal concentration variation of Cr­(VI) reduction at different pH values is shown in b. Obviously, the reduction process was greatly accelerated by decreasing the pH values. This result is consistent with other reports on aqueous Cr­(VI) reduction by MOFs photocatalysts. Under acid conditions, the Cr2O7 2– anion is predominant in the solution, and the reduction proceeds as : 14 H + + Cr 2 O 7 2 − + 6 e − → 2 Cr 3 + + 7 H 2 O
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Reduction of Cr(VI)

The use of NNU-36 as a visible light photocatalyst for the reduction of aqueous Cr(VI) was performed since it shows broad-range visible light absorption and good stability. Control experiments were first carried out to illustrate the photocatalytic nature of the reaction. As shown in a, there is no significant reduction of Cr(VI) in the dark or in the absence of a photocatalyst. It is well-known that the reduction rate of aqueous Cr(VI) over photocatalysts is greatly influenced by pH values of the solution. Hence, the influence of pH values on the reaction was investigated. The temporal concentration variation of Cr(VI) reduction at different pH values is shown in b. Obviously, the reduction process was greatly accelerated by decreasing the pH values. This result is consistent with other reports on aqueous Cr(VI) reduction by MOFs photocatalysts. Under acid conditions, the Cr2O7 2- anion is predominant in the solution, and the reduction proceeds as : 1    14   H   +   +   Cr   2       O   7     2 -   + 6   e   -   → 2   Cr   3 +   + 7   H   2   O

elements.content: (a) Control experiments for the reduction of Cr­(VI) under different conditions; (b) photocatalytic reduction of Cr­(VI) over NNU-36 at different pH values; (c) photocatalytic reduction of Cr­(VI) with different methanol addition; (d) time-dependent absorption spectra for the reaction of phtocatalytic reduction of Cr­(VI) with methanol (2 mL) at pH 2.17; (e) pseudo-first-order kinetics curves of photocatalytic Cr­(VI) reduction reactions over NNU-36 under different conditions; (f) comparison of the apparent reaction rate constants of Cr­(VI) reduction reactions under different conditions.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Control experiments for the reduction of Cr(VI) under different conditions; (b) photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) over NNU-36 at different pH values; (c) photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) with different methanol addition; (d) time-dependent absorption spectra for the reaction of phtocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) with methanol (2 mL) at pH 2.17; (e) pseudo-first-order kinetics curves of photocatalytic Cr(VI) reduction reactions over NNU-36 under different conditions; (f) comparison of the apparent reaction rate constants of Cr(VI) reduction reactions under different conditions.

elements.content: Therefore, it is apparent that the lower pH value facilitates the photocatalytic reduction of Cr­(VI) because of the existence of abundant protons. In order to verify the reduction of Cr­(VI) to Cr­(III) in our experiment, the valence state of Cr ions bound to NNU-36 after catalytic reaction was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Cr 2p peaks in high resolution spectra (Figure S8) can be fitted by three components at binding energies of 577.3, 580.7, and 586.8 eV. The peaks at binding energies of 577.3 and 580.7 eV (Cr 2p3/2) can be attributed to Cr­(III), while the peak at 586.7 eV (Cr 2p1/2) can be ascribed to Cr­(VI). The XPS result indicates the Cr­(VI) is indeed reduced to Cr­(III).
elements.clean_text: Therefore, it is apparent that the lower pH value facilitates the photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) because of the existence of abundant protons. In order to verify the reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) in our experiment, the valence state of Cr ions bound to NNU-36 after catalytic reaction was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Cr 2p peaks in high resolution spectra (Figure S8) can be fitted by three components at binding energies of 577.3, 580.7, and 586.8 eV. The peaks at binding energies of 577.3 and 580.7 eV (Cr 2p3/2) can be attributed to Cr(III), while the peak at 586.7 eV (Cr 2p1/2) can be ascribed to Cr(VI). The XPS result indicates the Cr(VI) is indeed reduced to Cr(III).

elements.content: To further promote the photocatalytic reduction of Cr­(VI), methanol was added as a scavenger in the reaction where methanol would interact with the photoinduced holes in the VB of NNU-36. In order to explore the influence of methanol dosage on the reaction, different amounts of methanol were added where the reactions were all in acid condition with the same pH value of 2.17. As shown in c, the addition of methanol indeed promotes the photocatalytic activity of NNU-36 for the reduction of Cr­(VI). It seems that the higher the amoutn of methanol added, the faster is the reduction of Cr­(VI). Experiments also show that the addition of 2 mL is adequate for the reaction. d displays the time-dependent spectral changes of the DPC–Cr­(VI) complex solution at various reaction intervals under pH 2.17 when 2 mL of methanol was added. Results show that about 95.3% of the Cr­(VI) in the photocatalytic reaction could be reduced after 60 min. The reduction mediated by methanol is efficient as the photoinduced holes in photocatalyst NNU-36 could interact with the reductive methanol, thereby limiting the recombination between photoinduced electrons and holes to accelerate the target reaction. The reduction of Cr­(VI) approximately followed pseudo-first-order kinetics with a rate constant of 0.0471 min–1, as evidenced by the linear plot of ln­(C 0/C t ) vs reaction time t (e and f). It is notable that the Cr­(VI) reduction by NNU-36 is more efficient than those shown by BN/BiOCl, Ni3S2/graphene oxide (RGO), and RGO/UiO-66­(NH2) composites.
elements.clean_text: To further promote the photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI), methanol was added as a scavenger in the reaction where methanol would interact with the photoinduced holes in the VB of NNU-36. In order to explore the influence of methanol dosage on the reaction, different amounts of methanol were added where the reactions were all in acid condition with the same pH value of 2.17. As shown in c, the addition of methanol indeed promotes the photocatalytic activity of NNU-36 for the reduction of Cr(VI). It seems that the higher the amoutn of methanol added, the faster is the reduction of Cr(VI). Experiments also show that the addition of 2 mL is adequate for the reaction. d displays the time-dependent spectral changes of the DPC-Cr(VI) complex solution at various reaction intervals under pH 2.17 when 2 mL of methanol was added. Results show that about 95.3% of the Cr(VI) in the photocatalytic reaction could be reduced after 60 min. The reduction mediated by methanol is efficient as the photoinduced holes in photocatalyst NNU-36 could interact with the reductive methanol, thereby limiting the recombination between photoinduced electrons and holes to accelerate the target reaction. The reduction of Cr(VI) approximately followed pseudo-first-order kinetics with a rate constant of 0.0471 min-1, as evidenced by the linear plot of ln(C 0/C  t ) vs reaction time t (e and f). It is notable that the Cr(VI) reduction by NNU-36 is more efficient than those shown by BN/BiOCl, Ni3S2/graphene oxide (RGO), and RGO/UiO-66(NH2) composites.

elements.content: In the photocatalytic Cr­(VI) reduction reaction, photogenerated electrons in CB of MOF photocatalyst is believed to have strong reductive ability to attack stable Cr2O7 2– under acidic conditions. To confirm this, a trapping experiment was carried out by the addition of an electron scavenger of AgNO3 in the reaction (Figure S9). In contrast to the reaction without AgNO3, the photocatalytic Cr­(VI) reduction efficiency was decreased by 33.2% within 60 min, and the apparent reaction rate constant was declined to 0.0142 min–1.
elements.clean_text: In the photocatalytic Cr(VI) reduction reaction, photogenerated electrons in CB of MOF photocatalyst is believed to have strong reductive ability to attack stable Cr2O7 2- under acidic conditions. To confirm this, a trapping experiment was carried out by the addition of an electron scavenger of AgNO3 in the reaction (Figure S9). In contrast to the reaction without AgNO3, the photocatalytic Cr(VI) reduction efficiency was decreased by 33.2% within 60 min, and the apparent reaction rate constant was declined to 0.0142 min-1.

elements.content: It is well known that the stability and reusability of the photocatalyst are crucial for its catalytic application. The photocatalyst was recovered by filtration after Cr­(VI) reduction, washing with deionized water and ethanol, and then drying under room temperature. As shown in Figure S10, photocatalytic experiments reveal that the catalyst NNU-36 retains its catalytic activity even after four cycles of the reaction, where very little decrease of activity is observed. Characterizations including PXRD, FTIR, SEM, UV–vis spectra, and photoluminescence indicate that NNU-36 is stable enough to survive from the reaction by keeping the original crystal structure (Figures S11 and S12).
elements.clean_text: It is well known that the stability and reusability of the photocatalyst are crucial for its catalytic application. The photocatalyst was recovered by filtration after Cr(VI) reduction, washing with deionized water and ethanol, and then drying under room temperature. As shown in Figure S10, photocatalytic experiments reveal that the catalyst NNU-36 retains its catalytic activity even after four cycles of the reaction, where very little decrease of activity is observed. Characterizations including PXRD, FTIR, SEM, UV-vis spectra, and photoluminescence indicate that NNU-36 is stable enough to survive from the reaction by keeping the original crystal structure (Figures S11 and S12).

elements.content: Rhodamine B is chosen as a representative dye to evaluate the capability of NNU-36 for organic pollutions degradation. Control experiments were first conducted to illustrate the photocatalytic nature of the reaction. As shown in a, no significant variation of RhB concentration is observed under visible light irradiation, indicating that RhB is resistant to visible light irradiation. The variation of RhB concentration is negligible when NNU-36 was added in the dark, suggesting that the RhB molecule cannot be loaded into MOF photocatalysts due to the dense structure. The photocatalytic reaction reveals that 46.6% of RhB in the reaction is degraded within 70 min under visible light irradiation. This result shows that NNU-36 is photocatalytically active for RhB degradation under visible light irradiation, but the degradation rate is not very fast. The unsatisfactory photocatalytic efficiencies might result from the relatively fast recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes, as evidenced in the studies of Cr­(VI) reduction. To enhance the photocatalytic performance of MOFs, a feasible and important strategy is the addition of oxidants as electron acceptors in the reaction to reduce charge carrier recombination probability, owing to the immediate trapping of photogenerated electrons by the oxidants. Thus, the introduction of an environmentally benign oxidant of H2O2 to promote the catalytic reaction is an attractive solution.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Degradation of Dyes

Rhodamine B is chosen as a representative dye to evaluate the capability of NNU-36 for organic pollutions degradation. Control experiments were first conducted to illustrate the photocatalytic nature of the reaction. As shown in a, no significant variation of RhB concentration is observed under visible light irradiation, indicating that RhB is resistant to visible light irradiation. The variation of RhB concentration is negligible when NNU-36 was added in the dark, suggesting that the RhB molecule cannot be loaded into MOF photocatalysts due to the dense structure. The photocatalytic reaction reveals that 46.6% of RhB in the reaction is degraded within 70 min under visible light irradiation. This result shows that NNU-36 is photocatalytically active for RhB degradation under visible light irradiation, but the degradation rate is not very fast. The unsatisfactory photocatalytic efficiencies might result from the relatively fast recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes, as evidenced in the studies of Cr(VI) reduction. To enhance the photocatalytic performance of MOFs, a feasible and important strategy is the addition of oxidants as electron acceptors in the reaction to reduce charge carrier recombination probability, owing to the immediate trapping of photogenerated electrons by the oxidants. Thus, the introduction of an environmentally benign oxidant of H2O2 to promote the catalytic reaction is an attractive solution.

elements.content: (a) Control experiments for the photocatalytic degradation of RhB over NNU-36. (b) Photocatalytic degradation reactions over NNU-36 with different H2O2 addition; (c) comparative experiments showing different degradation performances by the addition of H2O2; (d) time-dependent absorption spectra for the photocatalytic reaction of RhB degradation with H2O2 (1.0 M); (e) pseudo-first-order kinetics curves of the photocatalytic degradation of RhB over NNU-36 under different conditions; and (f) comparison of the apparent reaction rate constants for the degradation of RhB under different conditions.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Control experiments for the photocatalytic degradation of RhB over NNU-36. (b) Photocatalytic degradation reactions over NNU-36 with different H2O2 addition; (c) comparative experiments showing different degradation performances by the addition of H2O2; (d) time-dependent absorption spectra for the photocatalytic reaction of RhB degradation with H2O2 (1.0 M); (e) pseudo-first-order kinetics curves of the photocatalytic degradation of RhB over NNU-36 under different conditions; and (f) comparison of the apparent reaction rate constants for the degradation of RhB under different conditions.

elements.content: The effect of H2O2 dosage on RhB degradation over the NNU-36/visible light/H2O2 system was investigated by varying H2O2 concentration under the given reaction conditions. As depicted in a and b, the use of H2O2 significantly enhances the degradation efficiency of RhB. The degradation rate of RhB reaches a maximum value when 1.0 M H2O2 is added. As much as 96.2% of RhB in the reaction was degraded after 70 min of visible light irradiation (d). These results indicate that H2O2-involved AOP is efficient for photocatalytic degradation of dyes by producing active hydroxyl radicals (). However, the degradation efficiency was not improved but kept constant when the dosage of H2O2 was further increased. This can be rationalized as surplus H2O2 molecules act as scavenger of ·OH radicals to generate perhydroxy radicals with lower oxidation potential (). H 2 O 2 + e − → OH · + OH − H 2 O 2 + OH · → H 2 O + HOO ·
elements.clean_text: The effect of H2O2 dosage on RhB degradation over the NNU-36/visible light/H2O2 system was investigated by varying H2O2 concentration under the given reaction conditions. As depicted in a and b, the use of H2O2 significantly enhances the degradation efficiency of RhB. The degradation rate of RhB reaches a maximum value when 1.0 M H2O2 is added. As much as 96.2% of RhB in the reaction was degraded after 70 min of visible light irradiation (d). These results indicate that H2O2-involved AOP is efficient for photocatalytic degradation of dyes by producing active hydroxyl radicals (). However, the degradation efficiency was not improved but kept constant when the dosage of H2O2 was further increased. This can be rationalized as surplus H2O2 molecules act as scavenger of ⋅OH radicals to generate perhydroxy radicals with lower oxidation potential (). 2      H   2     O   2   +   e   -   → OH ⋅ +   OH   -       3      H   2     O   2   + OH ⋅ →   H   2   O + HOO ⋅

elements.content: As shown by the linear plot of ln­(C 0/C t) vs reaction time t (e), the degradation of RhB followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. As we can see from f, the NNU-36/RhB/H2O2 system exhibited a significantly faster apparent rate constant of 0.0468 min–1, which is over 5 times higher than that of the NNU-36/RhB system (0.0087 min–1) and about 10 times faster than that of the RhB/H2O2 system (0.0044 min–1). As indicated by the rate constant, NNU-36 is comparable with other MOFs photocatalysts for RhB degradation. These results demonstrate clearly that the H2O2-involved AOP is powerful to accelerate the photocatalytic degradation efficiency over NNU-36. As generally accepted, hydroxyl radicals (·OH) are the crucial active species in the H2O2-involved photocatalytic dye degradation over MOFs. This is investigated by using tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) as scavengers of hydroxyl radicals in the reaction. As illustrated in Figure S13, the addition of TBA depressed the photocatalytic efficiency. In the presence of TBA, about 85.8% of RhB in the reaction was degraded at 70 min, and the apparent reaction rate constant was decreased to one-half (ca. 0.0263 min–1) of that for the reaction without TBA. Besides, it is interesting to find that the addition order of H2O2 plays an important influence on the degradation efficiency. As shown in c, when H2O2 (1.0 M) was added into the suspension of RhB and NNU-36 for 60 min before visible light irradiation, about 69.3% of RhB was photocatalytically degraded after 70 min. In contrast, about 96.2% of RhB was degraded within the same time if H2O2 was added just after the suspension had been irradiated.
elements.clean_text: As shown by the linear plot of ln(C 0/C t) vs reaction time t (e), the degradation of RhB followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. As we can see from f, the NNU-36/RhB/H2O2 system exhibited a significantly faster apparent rate constant of 0.0468 min-1, which is over 5 times higher than that of the NNU-36/RhB system (0.0087 min-1) and about 10 times faster than that of the RhB/H2O2 system (0.0044 min-1). As indicated by the rate constant, NNU-36 is comparable with other MOFs photocatalysts for RhB degradation. These results demonstrate clearly that the H2O2-involved AOP is powerful to accelerate the photocatalytic degradation efficiency over NNU-36. As generally accepted, hydroxyl radicals (⋅OH) are the crucial active species in the H2O2-involved photocatalytic dye degradation over MOFs. This is investigated by using tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) as scavengers of hydroxyl radicals in the reaction. As illustrated in Figure S13, the addition of TBA depressed the photocatalytic efficiency. In the presence of TBA, about 85.8% of RhB in the reaction was degraded at 70 min, and the apparent reaction rate constant was decreased to one-half (ca. 0.0263 min-1) of that for the reaction without TBA. Besides, it is interesting to find that the addition order of H2O2 plays an important influence on the degradation efficiency. As shown in c, when H2O2 (1.0 M) was added into the suspension of RhB and NNU-36 for 60 min before visible light irradiation, about 69.3% of RhB was photocatalytically degraded after 70 min. In contrast, about 96.2% of RhB was degraded within the same time if H2O2 was added just after the suspension had been irradiated.

elements.content: To further investigate the photocatalytic activity of NNU-36 on organic dyes, the photocatalytic degradation of MB and R6G was explored under consistent conditions with RhB. The results are shown in . It is clear that the presence of H2O2 dramatically enhanced the catalytic reaction. The degradation efficiency of MB was 94.2% after 80 min of visible light irradiation, and the degradation efficiency of R6G was 93.5% after 90 min. The same as the reaction of RhB, both reactions for MB and R6G approximately followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. The apparent rate constants of MB and R6G were 0.0315 min–1 and 0.0292 min–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text: To further investigate the photocatalytic activity of NNU-36 on organic dyes, the photocatalytic degradation of MB and R6G was explored under consistent conditions with RhB. The results are shown in . It is clear that the presence of H2O2 dramatically enhanced the catalytic reaction. The degradation efficiency of MB was 94.2% after 80 min of visible light irradiation, and the degradation efficiency of R6G was 93.5% after 90 min. The same as the reaction of RhB, both reactions for MB and R6G approximately followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. The apparent rate constants of MB and R6G were 0.0315 min-1 and 0.0292 min-1, respectively.

elements.content: (a,b) Control experiments to show the photocatalytic activities of NNU-36 for the degradation of MB (a) and R6G (b), in which 1.0 M H2O2 was used for both reactions. (c,d) Comparison of the apparent reaction rate constants for the degradation of MB (c) and R6G (d) under different conditions.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a,b) Control experiments to show the photocatalytic activities of NNU-36 for the degradation of MB (a) and R6G (b), in which 1.0 M H2O2 was used for both reactions. (c,d) Comparison of the apparent reaction rate constants for the degradation of MB (c) and R6G (d) under different conditions.

elements.content: To evaluate the stability of photocatalyst NNU-36, recycling reactions of RhB degradation were carried out under visible light irradiation. As shown in Figure S14, NNU-36 keeps its photocatalytic activity after four cycles showing very slight loss of catalytic activity. The catalyst of NNU-36 after four cycles was collected by centrifugation. Measurements of PXRD, FTIR, SEM, UV–vis, and photoluminescence (Figures S15 and S16) suggest that NNU-36 is stable during the degradation reactions.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the stability of photocatalyst NNU-36, recycling reactions of RhB degradation were carried out under visible light irradiation. As shown in Figure S14, NNU-36 keeps its photocatalytic activity after four cycles showing very slight loss of catalytic activity. The catalyst of NNU-36 after four cycles was collected by centrifugation. Measurements of PXRD, FTIR, SEM, UV-vis, and photoluminescence (Figures S15 and S16) suggest that NNU-36 is stable during the degradation reactions.

elements.content: On the basis of the experimental results of Cr­(VI) reduction and dye degradation, a plausible mechanism for NNU-36 mediated photocatalysis is proposed and illustrated in . The pillared ligand of BPEA in the structure serves as an optical absorbance center. Upon visible light irradiation, the photogenerated electron–hole pairs would separate through the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) process, leaving a photoinduced electron (e–) in the conduction band and a positive-charged hole (h+) in the valence band of NNU-36 (). Then the photogenerated electrons in the CB are transferred to reduce the Cr­(VI) ions on the surface of NNU-36 (), while the holes oxidize the hole scavenger to form CO2 and H2O and other minerals (). The introduction of a hole scavenger such as methanol has been proved to be effective to promote the photocatalytic Cr­(VI) reduction over NNU-36 in our experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism

On the basis of the experimental results of Cr(VI) reduction and dye degradation, a plausible mechanism for NNU-36 mediated photocatalysis is proposed and illustrated in . The pillared ligand of BPEA in the structure serves as an optical absorbance center. Upon visible light irradiation, the photogenerated electron-hole pairs would separate through the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) process, leaving a photoinduced electron (e-) in the conduction band and a positive-charged hole (h+) in the valence band of NNU-36 (). Then the photogenerated electrons in the CB are transferred to reduce the Cr(VI) ions on the surface of NNU-36 (), while the holes oxidize the hole scavenger to form CO2 and H2O and other minerals (). The introduction of a hole scavenger such as methanol has been proved to be effective to promote the photocatalytic Cr(VI) reduction over NNU-36 in our experiments.

elements.content: Schematic illustration of photocatalytic reduction Cr­(VI) and degradation of dyes over NNU-36 under visible light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: 6  Schematic illustration of photocatalytic reduction Cr(VI) and degradation of dyes over NNU-36 under visible light irradiation.

elements.content: As for reactions of dye degradation, the enhanced photocatalytic rate should be attributed to the scavenging of the photogenerated electrons in the conduction band of NNU-36 by external an electron acceptor of H2O2, which hinders the recombination of electrons and holes efficiently. The resulting hydroxyl radicals (·OH) have a strong oxidation capacity to decompose dye molecules into CO2 and H2O and others (). The photoinduced holes of NNU-36 could further accelerate the degradation by oxidizing the dye molecule directly. It is also believed that some holes would oxidize the ligand itself leading to a slight decrease of catalytic activity during cycling experiment. In view that both Cr­(VI) reduction and dye degradation of NNU-36 rely on the photoinduced electron, the simultaneous removal of these pollutants by NNU-36 was also investigated. As displayed in Figure S17, it can be seen that the Cr­(VI) reduction and dye degradation proceeded at the same time. The photocatalytic experiments of Cr­(VI) reduction and dye degradation indicate that the addition of hole scavengers or oxidants in the MOF mediated photocatalytic reaction is a feasible approach to enhance the catalytic efficiency by suppressing the recombination of photogenerated electron–hole pairs in MOFs photocatalysts. NNU‐ 36 + h ν → NNU‐ 36 ( e − + h + ) methanol + h + → CO 2 + H 2 O + others dye + · OH → CO 2 + H 2 O + others
elements.clean_text: As for reactions of dye degradation, the enhanced photocatalytic rate should be attributed to the scavenging of the photogenerated electrons in the conduction band of NNU-36 by external an electron acceptor of H2O2, which hinders the recombination of electrons and holes efficiently. The resulting hydroxyl radicals (⋅OH) have a strong oxidation capacity to decompose dye molecules into CO2 and H2O and others (). The photoinduced holes of NNU-36 could further accelerate the degradation by oxidizing the dye molecule directly. It is also believed that some holes would oxidize the ligand itself leading to a slight decrease of catalytic activity during cycling experiment. In view that both Cr(VI) reduction and dye degradation of NNU-36 rely on the photoinduced electron, the simultaneous removal of these pollutants by NNU-36 was also investigated. As displayed in Figure S17, it can be seen that the Cr(VI) reduction and dye degradation proceeded at the same time. The photocatalytic experiments of Cr(VI) reduction and dye degradation indicate that the addition of hole scavengers or oxidants in the MOF mediated photocatalytic reaction is a feasible approach to enhance the catalytic efficiency by suppressing the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs in MOFs photocatalysts. 4    NNU- 36 + h ν → NNU- 36  (   e   -   +   h   +   )      5    methanol +   h   +   →   CO   2   +   H   2   O + others     6    dye + ⋅ OH →   CO   2   +   H   2   O + others

elements.content: In summary, a novel visible light photocatalyst of the zinc metal–organic framework NNU-36 has been prepared by the pillared-layer synthetic approach using visible light harvesting the pillared ligand of anthracene derived bipyridine. It has been demonstrated that NNU-36 is a highly efficient heterogeneous photocatalyst for aqueous Cr­(VI) reduction and degradation of dyes. Experiments reveal that the photocatalytic reduction of Cr­(VI) to Cr­(III) is highly pH-dependent, and the addition of hole scavenger of methanol significantly promotes the photocatalytic reaction. Meanwhile, hydrogen peroxide has been proved to be effective to enhance the photocatalytic degradation of different dyes through an advanced oxidation process. Results also reveal that NNU-36 is stable, enabling it to be a potential candidate for wastewater treatment. The success of NNU-36 suggests that the incorporation of a chromophore into the ligand is feasible to introduce desirable visible light response in MOFs. What is more, the structural characteristics of the pillared-layer framework and paddlewheel building unit shown by NNU-36 indicate that the pillared-layer approach is a controllable method to design and synthesize functional MOFs materials, such as photocatalysts. It is expected that more efficient MOF photocatalysts could be synthesized toward the goal of environmental restoration by utilizing solar energy.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a novel visible light photocatalyst of the zinc metal-organic framework NNU-36 has been prepared by the pillared-layer synthetic approach using visible light harvesting the pillared ligand of anthracene derived bipyridine. It has been demonstrated that NNU-36 is a highly efficient heterogeneous photocatalyst for aqueous Cr(VI) reduction and degradation of dyes. Experiments reveal that the photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) is highly pH-dependent, and the addition of hole scavenger of methanol significantly promotes the photocatalytic reaction. Meanwhile, hydrogen peroxide has been proved to be effective to enhance the photocatalytic degradation of different dyes through an advanced oxidation process. Results also reveal that NNU-36 is stable, enabling it to be a potential candidate for wastewater treatment. The success of NNU-36 suggests that the incorporation of a chromophore into the ligand is feasible to introduce desirable visible light response in MOFs. What is more, the structural characteristics of the pillared-layer framework and paddlewheel building unit shown by NNU-36 indicate that the pillared-layer approach is a controllable method to design and synthesize functional MOFs materials, such as photocatalysts. It is expected that more efficient MOF photocatalysts could be synthesized toward the goal of environmental restoration by utilizing solar energy.

cln_elements.content: All chemicals except the pillaring ligand of 9,10-bis­(4′-pyridylethynyl)-anthracene (BPEA) (see Supporting Information) are of analytical grade and used as received from suppliers without further purification. Pillared-layer MOF (named NNU-36) was solvothermally prepared by a reaction of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (47 mg, 0.16 mmol), BPEA (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), and 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate (BPDC) (38 mg, 0.15 mmol) dissolved in a mixed solvent of DMF/DMA/H2O (19 mL, 11:4:4, v/v/v). The reaction was carried out in an autoclave and kept at 85 °C for 3 days. Brown plate-shaped single crystals of NNU-36 were obtained and washed with DMF and ethanol several times for further use. Yield: ca. 65.5% based on BPEA. The details of single-crystal data collection and refinement, as well as physical characterizations for bulk samples are provided in Supporting Information.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of Pillared-Layer NNU-36

All chemicals except the pillaring ligand of 9,10-bis(4'-pyridylethynyl)-anthracene (BPEA) (see Supporting Information) are of analytical grade and used as received from suppliers without further purification. Pillared-layer MOF (named NNU-36) was solvothermally prepared by a reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (47 mg, 0.16 mmol), BPEA (30 mg, 0.08 mmol), and 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (BPDC) (38 mg, 0.15 mmol) dissolved in a mixed solvent of DMF/DMA/H2O (19 mL, 11:4:4, v/v/v). The reaction was carried out in an autoclave and kept at 85 °C for 3 days. Brown plate-shaped single crystals of NNU-36 were obtained and washed with DMF and ethanol several times for further use. Yield: ca. 65.5% based on BPEA. The details of single-crystal data collection and refinement, as well as physical characterizations for bulk samples are provided in Supporting Information.

cln_elements.content: To further investigate the photocatalytic activity of NNU-36 on organic dyes, the photocatalytic degradation of MB and R6G was explored under consistent conditions with RhB. The results are shown in . It is clear that the presence of H2O2 dramatically enhanced the catalytic reaction. The degradation efficiency of MB was 94.2% after 80 min of visible light irradiation, and the degradation efficiency of R6G was 93.5% after 90 min. The same as the reaction of RhB, both reactions for MB and R6G approximately followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. The apparent rate constants of MB and R6G were 0.0315 min–1 and 0.0292 min–1, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: To further investigate the photocatalytic activity of NNU-36 on organic dyes, the photocatalytic degradation of MB and R6G was explored under consistent conditions with RhB. The results are shown in . It is clear that the presence of H2O2 dramatically enhanced the catalytic reaction. The degradation efficiency of MB was 94.2% after 80 min of visible light irradiation, and the degradation efficiency of R6G was 93.5% after 90 min. The same as the reaction of RhB, both reactions for MB and R6G approximately followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. The apparent rate constants of MB and R6G were 0.0315 min-1 and 0.0292 min-1, respectively.

metadata.title:
Construction of Pillared-Layer MOF as Efficient Visible-Light
Photocatalysts for Aqueous Cr(VI) Reduction and Dye Degradation
